What are the minimum hardware requirements for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The minimum hardware requirements for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node include a X86/X64 compatible CPU with 24 cores/48 threads, 256 GB memory, 5TB of SSD NVMe usable storage, and specific storage performance benchmarks for sequential write sustained, sequential read sustained, random read, random write, and more. Additionally, the node must pass the Hedera performance test suite performed at installation time.

What software is required for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The software required for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node includes Docker Engine, Docker Compose, IPTables Support, Havege Daemon, HashDeep Utilities, Bindplane Collector, JQ CLI, GNU CoreUtils, cURL CLI, InCron Daemon, Rsync CLI, and Node Management Tools, among others. Details about version requirements and dependencies are also provided in the information base.

What are the network connectivity requirements for a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The network connectivity requirements for a Hedera Mainnet consensus node include sustained 1Gb/s internet bandwidth, dedicated (isolated) DMZ network deployment, specific open ports, static IP address, and unmetered internet connectivity is preferred. Additionally, an in-line proxy is required to mediate access to the node via public APIs, and specific specifications for establishing this proxy are mentioned in the information base.

What are the details regarding the proxy required for a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The required details for the proxy to be used for a Hedera Mainnet consensus node include 2-core-x86/x64 CPU, 2GB RAM, 100GB SSD storage, 200Mb/s sustained internet network connectivity with a public static IP address, and the supported Docker version. The necessary specifications for the proxy connectivity and interface bonding are also provided in the information base.

What are the operating system and system user account requirements for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The operating system requirement for a Hedera Mainnet consensus node is Linux with specific kernel version and Docker Engine and Docker Compose versions. Additionally, detailed specifications regarding the system user accounts, including the mandatory 'hedera' user account, its permissions, group membership, and specifications are provided in the information base.

What hosting requirements are necessary for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The hosting requirements for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node include industry-standard hosting requirements for security and availability, Tier 1 Data Center Hosting facility, and compliance with specific standards such as SSAE 16/18, SOC 2 Type 2. Moreover, the avoidance of duplicating hosting providers across Council members is emphasized in the information base.

What are the deployment steps for adding a consensus node to the Hedera Mainnet?

The deployment steps for adding a consensus node to the Hedera Mainnet include initial contact with Council Member and node hosting entity, conveyance of technical requirements, acquisition of node platform, configuration of the operating system, conveyance of credentials to Hedera, deployment of consensus node software and supporting libraries, review of test results, determination of preparedness for mainnet connectivity, scheduling of mainnet connection, and finally going live on the mainnet. Each step is outlined in detail in the provided information base.

Which Linux distributions are approved for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The approved 64-bit Long Term Support (LTS) Linux distributions for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node include Ubuntu, Red Hat Enterprise, Oracle Linux, and CentOS (Only through 2023). Details regarding the specific minimum kernel version and active long-term support release are also provided in the information base.

What tests must the nodes pass to qualify for the Hedera Mainnet?

The nodes must pass the Hedera performance test suite performed at installation time to qualify for the Hedera Mainnet. This suite includes functional, stability, and performance tests for all network services, and it is executed by Hedera prior to the mainnet connection schedule.

What specifications are provided for the network connectivity of the Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The specifications for the network connectivity of the Hedera Mainnet consensus node include 1Gbps internet connectivity, deployment in a dedicated (isolated) DMZ network with specific open ports, unmetered internet connectivity is preferred, access to public APIs must be mediated by an in-line proxy, and detailed requirements for the proxy are specified in the information base.

What specific performance benchmarks are required for the storage of a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The specific performance benchmarks required for the storage of a Hedera Mainnet consensus node include sequential write sustained, sequential read sustained, random read, random write, and less than 200B5s random read latency, average. These benchmarks are important for the root volume and RAID array storage performance, and they are outlined in the information base with minimum and recommended values.

What is the purpose of the Havege Daemon in deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

The Havege Daemon is required for deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node if privileged container support is disabled. It is mentioned as an optional requirement, and its version specified in the information base, along with other necessary software and utilities for node deployment.

What is the purpose of the HashDeep Utilities in deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node?

HashDeep Utilities are required for update integrity validation in the context of deploying a Hedera Mainnet consensus node. The specified version (4.4) is included in the list of necessary software and utilities provided in the information base.
